data.sampled:
Sure! Here's the solution to the task:

Blue x Blue -> 3/4 Blue 1/4 Green

The possible genotypes of the parents are:

1. BB (both parents have the B allele)
2. BG (one parent has the B allele, the other has the G allele)
3. GG (both parents have the G allele)

The possible phenotypes of the offspring are:

1. BB (both parents have the B allele, so all offspring will have the B allele and be blue)
2. BG (one parent has the B allele, the other has the G allele, so 3/4 of the offspring will have the B allele and be blue, and 1/4 will have the G allele and be green)
3. GG (both parents have the G allele, so all offspring will have the G allele and be green)

Therefore, the genotypes of the parents and offspring are as follows:

Parents:

1. BB (both parents have the B allele)
2. BG (one parent has the B allele, the other has the G allele)

Offspring:

1. BB (3/4 blue, 1/4 green)
2. BG (3/4 blue, 1/4 green)
3. GG (all green)

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any other questions.

data.sampled:
Sure! Here's the solution:

Blue x Blue -> 3/4 Blue 1/4 Green

Parents:

* Parent 1: BB (Blue)
* Parent 2: BB (Blue)

Offspring:

* 3/4 BB (Blue) x 3/4 BB (Blue) = 3/4 BB (Blue) x 1/4 BG (Green) = 3/4 BB (Blue) + 1/2 BG (Green)
* 1/4 BG (Green) x 3/4 BB (Blue) = 1/4 BG (Green) x 1/4 BG (Green) = 1/2 BB (Blue) + 1/2 BG (Green)

So, the genotypes of the offspring are:

* 3/4 BB (Blue) x 3/4 BB (Blue) = BB x BB = 4/4 BB (Blue)
* 1/4 BG (Green) x 3/4 BB (Blue) = BG x BB = 1/2 BB (Blue) + 1/2 BG (Green)
* 3/4 BB (Blue) x 1/4 BG (Green) = BB x BG = 1/2 BB (Blue) + 1/2 BG (Green)

Therefore, the distribution of phenotypes in the F1 generation is:

* 3/4 Blue (BB)
* 1/4 Green (BG)
